description: From Middle English confessor, confessour, from Anglo-Norman confessour, and its source, Latin cōnfessor, from cōnfiteor (“confess, admit, acknowledge”).

entries.meaning: One who confesses faith in Christianity in the face of persecution, but who is not martyred.
examples: Confessors provided the troubled Church with an alternative sort of authority based on their sufferings, particularly when arguments began about how and how much to forgive those Christians who had given way to imperial orders – the so-called ‘lapsed’.

entries.meaning: One who confesses to having done something wrong.
(Roman Catholicism) A priest who hears confession and then gives absolution
